quotes.topic_title: Cold open: vision selling, pricing, differentiation
quotes.text: You need to vision cast, you need to sell to a gap, don't sell to a problem. When you're selling to a leader, you need to be selling an opportunity. The market doesn't want to be sold to, they want to buy.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical positioning framework: sell the future-state opportunity (the gap) rather than diagnosing pain, especially with executives.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: vision selling, pricing, differentiation
quotes.text: In the very early days, people will discount till the cows come home because they think that's the way to get a deal done. The best clients are not going to do that to you. If they're sitting there nickel-and-diming you, they're not fully bought in on what you're selling them.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A qualification and pricing heuristic: heavy discount pressure can signal low conviction and poor-fit customers.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: vision selling, pricing, differentiation
quotes.text: As soon as you become a comparison, as soon as you become one of three that they're testing out, you've already sort of lost. It's all about differentiation. Here's what you will be able to do tomorrow because of how we're going to serve you today.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A differentiation principle: avoid being slotted into bake-offs by anchoring on unique outcomes and delivery, not feature parity.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: vision selling, pricing, differentiation
quotes.text: It's more of an art. It's all about deal crafting. It is a relationship you're building with someone. If they know they can call on you, people will turn over rocks for you. I have a client at a Fortune 10 company where I was like, "It's so important we get the deal done this year. Is that possible?" And she's like, "It's a tall order, but if it's going to help you, let's do it." These are how enterprise deals gets done. It's relationships.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A concrete enterprise sales model and example showing how relationship capital enables creative deal-making and internal advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: vision selling, pricing, differentiation
quotes.text: I don't use a tool. The thing about AI tools is they're all pulling from the same databases. I want to email someone not in the database that's getting hit by a million folks. I want to take a back door in, not the front door where everyone else is trick or treating.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A contrarian outbound tactic: avoid crowded AI-driven channels and find less-saturated paths to reach prospects.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Our first conversation was focused around getting from zero to 1 million ARR, essentially founder led sales.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames a clear growth-stage milestone and positions founder-led sales as the core motion for reaching $1M ARR.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This conversation is part two going from around one million in ARR to around 10 million.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Defines the specific scaling window the episode will tackle, useful for practitioners benchmarking their sales evolution by ARR stage.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This is the most tactical and in the weeds discussion you will find anywhere for free on how to actually become more effective at selling to enterprises.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets expectations for highly actionable enterprise-sales tactics rather than high-level theory.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building software for enterprises, you've probably felt the pain of integrating single sign-on, SKIM, RBAC, audit logs and other features required by big customers.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Highlights the common enterprise “deal blocker” requirements teams should plan for when moving upmarket.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: WorkOS turns those deal blockers into drop-in APIs with a modern developer platform built specifically for B2B SaaS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Offers a practical approach—treat enterprise requirements as modular capabilities you can integrate quickly via APIs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're a seed-stage startup trying to land your first enterprise customer or a unicorn expanding globally, WorkOS is the fastest path to becoming enterprise-ready and unlocking growth.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Frames “enterprise-ready” as a growth unlock across stages, not something reserved for later maturity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Unlike no-code tools, Lovable isn't about static pages. It builds full apps with real functionality and it's fast.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Lovable)
quotes.context: Clarifies a key product distinction practitioners can use when choosing tools for prototyping vs. building functional apps.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What used to take weeks, months, or years, you can now do over a weekend.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Lovable)
quotes.context: A memorable speed benchmark that encourages teams to compress build cycles and validate ideas faster.

quotes.topic_title: Why the mid-market “doesn’t exist”
quotes.text: It's fascinating because if you ask someone to describe the mid-market, actually, if you ask someone to describe the enterprise, every single person has a different answer.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Highlights that common segment labels are ambiguous, which leads teams to misalign on who they’re selling to and how.

quotes.topic_title: Why the mid-market “doesn’t exist”
quotes.text: selling to a hundred person organization is a radically different game than selling to a thousand person organization and there's no hybrid approach.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A clear mental model: SMB vs enterprise motions are fundamentally different, so blending them creates execution risk.

quotes.topic_title: Why the mid-market “doesn’t exist”
quotes.text: So the best way to think about it is you have small business which typically can be really powered by marketing, and then you have enterprise, which is typically going to be sales led.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a practical segmentation heuristic tied directly to go-to-market motion (marketing-led vs sales-led).

quotes.topic_title: Why the mid-market “doesn’t exist”
quotes.text: Now, when we talk about mid-market, I usually will say, "Are we talking about the upper end of small business or are we talking about the lower end of enterprise?"
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: An actionable diagnostic question to force clarity on which playbook, hiring profile, and ACV targets apply.

quotes.topic_title: Why the mid-market “doesn’t exist”
quotes.text: So I say the mid-market doesn't exist because what is a mid-market hire? It's either low end enterprise or upper end SMB, and if you bleed those two games you're going to lose.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A memorable, contrarian takeaway that warns against mixing sales motions and roles across segments.

quotes.topic_title: Go after tier-one logos earlier
quotes.text: Power laws totally exist in these large corporations and we can't be treating everyone the same.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A segmentation mental model: enterprise accounts follow power laws, so go-to-market strategy must differentiate by tier rather than using a one-size-fits-all approach.

quotes.topic_title: Go after tier-one logos earlier
quotes.text: The exact opposite. Early adopters are those logos because they have to continue to stay at the number one spot.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Contrarian advice: instead of avoiding big logos early, target market leaders first because their competitive pressure makes them more willing to adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Go after tier-one logos earlier
quotes.text: So those number one logos are like if you can give me just a slight bit of alpha, just a tiny bit, that's where I get promoted, that's where I get the pat on the back because we are the world's leader in our industry and we cannot be disrupted there.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical buyer-motivation frame: position your product as “alpha” that helps champions win internally and defend leadership externally.

quotes.topic_title: Go after tier-one logos earlier
quotes.text: The ones that carry all the weight are the ones that are willing to take a shot and want to help, right? Because they also want to be, they also want to be able to dictate the roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Reframes tier-one accounts as collaborative early adopters who will engage to shape product direction—useful for roadmap and enterprise readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Go after tier-one logos earlier
quotes.text: in the age of AI where it's all about sucking the oxygen out of the room and winning the deal and getting your foot in the door as quickly as humanly possible before someone else tries to take that, you want to get to the enterprise as fast as humanly possible.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Tactical urgency: in fast-moving markets, prioritize speed to enterprise footholds to preempt competitors and lock in distribution/proof.

quotes.topic_title: How to approach enterprise: sell the gap
quotes.text: First of all, make sure the founder is involved, right? Everyone loves talking to a founder, so we'll start with let's get the founder involved as fast as human possible.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Tactical enterprise outreach advice: use founder-led selling early to increase credibility and engagement with large accounts.

quotes.topic_title: How to approach enterprise: sell the gap
quotes.text: The second is you need to vision cast, you need to sell to a gap, don't sell to a problem. There's a very big difference between problem selling and gap selling.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework (gap selling vs. problem selling) for how to message to enterprise leaders.

quotes.topic_title: How to approach enterprise: sell the gap
quotes.text: When you're selling to a leader, you need to be vision casting and you need to be selling an opportunity which is they are here, here's where we can take you.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Actionable messaging structure for enterprise execs: present a current-state to future-state opportunity narrative.

quotes.topic_title: How to approach enterprise: sell the gap
quotes.text: And that's why founders are so good at selling because they naturally go to vision selling and vision casting versus a typical trained salesperson is find the problem, ask these questions and it just kills the vibe.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Contrarian take: traditional discovery/problem interrogation can backfire with leaders; vision-led selling is more effective.

quotes.topic_title: How to approach enterprise: sell the gap
quotes.text: I think it may be more of you'll be able to actually hire the 10X engineers that you don't necessarily have access to because they want to be able to use this type of tool.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Concrete example of vision casting for Cursor: position the product as a talent magnet and competitive advantage, not just productivity.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing confidence: avoid small deals and discounting
quotes.text: The best clients are not going to do that to you because that's like a qualification criteria, which is like if they're sitting there nickel-and-diming you being like, "No, I don't believe it's worth this. I don't believe it's worth that." They're not fully bought in on what you're selling them.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Reframes discount pressure as a qualification signal that the buyer lacks conviction, helping founders avoid bad-fit deals.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing confidence: avoid small deals and discounting
quotes.text: So when I say I'd rather get $100,000 deal than $10,000 deals, I'd rather have one rock star client that's going to help me figure out the next stage of where this is going than 10 or maybe five that are a good fit, five that are not, and I still have to serve those five that are not a good fit, and that's going to distract me.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Argues for prioritizing fewer, higher-ACV customers to accelerate learning and avoid support drag from poor-fit accounts.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing confidence: avoid small deals and discounting
quotes.text: If you need to generate a hundred million dollars in revenue, how many 10K deals do you need? And the expansion on a 10K deal is in parallel to that. Where can you go? 10 to 15? That's a 50% growth, much easier to go to a 100K to 500K because they want more bodies or they want more value out of you.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a reverse-engineering revenue math model showing why small ACVs cap expansion and make scaling inefficient.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing confidence: avoid small deals and discounting
quotes.text: If you're venture-backed, you can't be selling $10,000 deals to the enterprise, you'll get killed, or you've already lost the game because you're playing a small business game in the wrong sector.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A blunt positioning warning that venture-scale expectations and enterprise motion require enterprise-level pricing and deal sizes.

quotes.topic_title: Pricing confidence: avoid small deals and discounting
quotes.text: Yeah, the math will break. And also, a really good salesperson, you're commissioned on a 10K deal, they're not going to get a great salesperson. They're going to want to be anchored to how can I sell a $250,000 deal? How can I sell a half a million dollar deal? That's the type of person you want.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Connects pricing strategy to talent strategy: low ACVs limit your ability to attract and motivate top enterprise sellers.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t anchor enterprise with SMB pricing
quotes.text: Ensure that you structure it for an enterprise. Don't play the small business team with an enterprise company.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A clear rule-of-thumb: when an enterprise shows up, switch to an enterprise motion instead of treating them like an SMB/PLG customer.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t anchor enterprise with SMB pricing
quotes.text: Very, very hard now to go from those three users that you just priced them at in a small business way, turn that into 100K because now it's documented what they're actually paying for this.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Explains the “pricing anchor” trap with a concrete example (Walmart buying a few seats) and why expansion becomes difficult once the low price is on record.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t anchor enterprise with SMB pricing
quotes.text: So you're stuck. You've kind of anchored yourself to this price.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Memorable summary of the core mental model: early pricing sets a reference point that constrains future enterprise deals.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t anchor enterprise with SMB pricing
quotes.text: It is enterprise companies are very used to a land, when I say the first initial contract, somewhat between 75K and 150K, very used to that.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a specific enterprise starting-range benchmark practitioners can use when setting initial contract sizes.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t anchor enterprise with SMB pricing
quotes.text: But who can really defend? That's very hard to defend a 10X. 10X jump, they're going to want to see 15X value.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that “great” expansion (10X) can backfire unless the value increase is even more clearly defensible.

quotes.topic_title: Design partners: choose wisely and set framing
quotes.text: Design partners are incredible. They're the hardest logos to upsell, meaning go from design partner to full rollout customer. So don't expect these people to be your million dollar pipeline. Expect these people to be the guide, to help you understand, maybe design partners could be a technology company in the Fortune 1,000.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Reframes design partners as a learning mechanism (not near-term revenue) and suggests a specific archetype: tech-forward Fortune 1000 companies.

quotes.topic_title: Design partners: choose wisely and set framing
quotes.text: But if you again frame it, say, "Listen, I would love for you to be a design partner. I want a little skin in the game to get you to point it. Here's where we want to go and you'll get a discount because you were in the beginning, but I'm setting the framing. Here's where we want to go with pricing. Here's where we are today. You'll always have 30% concession in perpetuity because you are there with us on day one."
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Gives a concrete “set the framing” script for design partners: require paid commitment, communicate pricing trajectory, and define a perpetual discount to avoid future renegotiation traps.

quotes.topic_title: Design partners: choose wisely and set framing
quotes.text: They sell everything. Yeah, design partner, even full rollout, and it's so, so important to tell them, "Here's where we are today. Here's what we cannot do." Which is just as important. It builds trust. "Here's what we will allow you to do in the next six months. Do you want to be on this journey with us? And it's really ugly right now." Right? "Barely anything exists, but we would love your voice to be a part of it."
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on managing expectations: explicitly state current limitations and near-term roadmap to build trust and reduce churn from overselling.

quotes.topic_title: Design partners: choose wisely and set framing
quotes.text: That is the founder's job. The founder's job is to have a clear vision and do not let anything delineate from that.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for avoiding design-partner-driven product drift: the founder must protect the vision while interpreting feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Design partners: choose wisely and set framing
quotes.text: And it's that 80/20 rule where 80% of what they're going to tell you is probably going to be not related to where you want to go or based off of the old way, but that 20% of, "Oh, I did not think about it that way." That drives everything.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a practical filter for design partner feedback: treat most input as legacy-thinking noise while hunting for the small set of insights that change your approach.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing SMB vs enterprise and AI-era constraints
quotes.text: I think it's about what game does the founder best understand? Are they an incredible marketer and have some competitive edge for how they can win a massive audience?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A founder-fit framework for choosing SMB vs enterprise based on the GTM “game” the founder can win.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing SMB vs enterprise and AI-era constraints
quotes.text: I would say go SMB and marketing led or are they a bit more really understand how large corporations work and really excited to deliver on $100,000 plus type of opportunities or the value that they are building for is way more relatable to an enterprise versus a small business.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Actionable decision rule: pick SMB/marketing-led vs enterprise/large-deal-led depending on strengths and value alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing SMB vs enterprise and AI-era constraints
quotes.text: I think we're going to see a lot more larger companies become smaller because of AI, not significantly smaller, but also high margins allow them to experiment more too.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive AI-era observation that “enterprise” may shift as headcount shrinks and experimentation increases.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing SMB vs enterprise and AI-era constraints
quotes.text: And it's much easier to get into the enterprise when you're like, "We won't even touch your data, won't even touch your data. Just use it to solve problems and then we can build trust and then start to integrate and connect the pipes."
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A low-risk land-and-expand methodology for enterprise adoption: start without data access, then earn trust to integrate.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing SMB vs enterprise and AI-era constraints
quotes.text: So you have to start small and low risk, which is like, "Hey, what is the subset of consumers that churned? Let's figure out how we could have made them happier, whatever it be." So that data is lower risk.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Concrete example of choosing a low-risk initial use case to overcome enterprise risk concerns around data/integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise sales as art: deal crafting and services
quotes.text: From one to 10, I think it's more of an art, which is how do I take my learning and how do I package it up where I own the framing, I can speak to very specific alpha, I can vision cast and where I better understand the problem over time better than the market does. And it's all about deal crafting.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A clear mental model for 1–10M enterprise sales: shift from experimentation to owning the narrative and creatively crafting deals.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise sales as art: deal crafting and services
quotes.text: They just need to feel like the value they're getting out of it is way more than the cost. And it's sometimes about giving away things that don't really cost much to you, but are super expensive for them.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Actionable deal-crafting tactic: offer high-perceived-value, low-cost concessions to tip ROI in your favor.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise sales as art: deal crafting and services
quotes.text: The product is pricing. The product is the opportunity, the framing and not letting them compare you to something else. And I know we talked that on our first call, which is as soon as you become a comparison, as soon as you become one of three that they're testing out, you've already sort of lost.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A differentiation framework: expand “product” to include framing and avoid competitive bake-offs where you become a commodity.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise sales as art: deal crafting and services
quotes.text: Enterprise is the number one thing they buy services, they know how to do it's super easy, they do it all of the time. It's like the most consistent thing they do. It's their largest budget item, external resources, consultants, whatever.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive go-to-market insight: services are often the easiest entry point because enterprises already have established buying motion and budget for them.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise sales as art: deal crafting and services
quotes.text: It's what they know how to buy. Now, the idea is to once you sell that surface, once you get that foot in the door, then it's to guide them towards the product. "Hey, you're spending so much here, why don't we get you to come in and leverage the tool that's been powering this the whole time and move this more into technology serving you versus the human."
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical land-and-expand methodology: start with a service wrapper, then transition the customer to the underlying product for scale and cost savings.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Imagine starting a project at work and your vision is clear, you know exactly who's doing what and where to find the data that you need to do your part.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an execution model where clarity of ownership and information access is designed upfront to reduce coordination overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In fact, you don't have to waste time searching for anything because everything your team needs from project trackers and OKRs, the documents and spreadsheets lives in one tab all in Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable principle: consolidate key operational artifacts (OKRs, trackers, docs, spreadsheets) into a single source of truth to eliminate time lost to searching.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Coda's collaborative all in one workspace, you get the flexibility of docs, the structure of spreadsheets, the power of applications, and the intelligence of AI, all in one easy to organize tab.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of an “all-in-one” workspace mental model combining multiple tool paradigms into one organized surface.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And more than 50,000 teams trust Coda to keep them more aligned and focused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point that signals product maturity and broad team usage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's a lot of talk these days about this idea forward deployed something volunteer was really famous for, just essentially an engineer sitting in your office solving problems with you basically as an employee. And then through that, they learn what software to build.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a customer-embedded product discovery methodology (“forward deployed”) where building follows hands-on problem solving in the customer environment.

quotes.topic_title: Forward-deployed, channels skepticism, and recap
quotes.text: The problem with channel partnerships and why I don't believe in them is there are a hundred of you on this list and you're expecting them to sell it on your behalf.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against relying on channel partners as a primary growth strategy because you’ll be one of many competing vendors.

quotes.topic_title: Forward-deployed, channels skepticism, and recap
quotes.text: I remember startups saying, "Oh, I'm going to go win over Accenture and then have them disseminate me into their clients." And I'm like, as if that's a workable strategy.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A memorable example of a common enterprise go-to-market fantasy that Jen argues is unrealistic in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Forward-deployed, channels skepticism, and recap
quotes.text: So advice one is go for tier one logos earlier than you think you should because they're early adopters, they can move fast, they can pull you in the right direction.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical GTM heuristic for $1M→$10M ARR: prioritize top-tier customers sooner because they accelerate learning and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Forward-deployed, channels skepticism, and recap
quotes.text: So the counterintuitive insight here is you think they will move slow and be too busy, but they are actually the early adopters.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that reframes big enterprises as faster-moving early adopters rather than slow, bureaucratic buyers.

quotes.topic_title: Forward-deployed, channels skepticism, and recap
quotes.text: So two is ideally try to price closer to about a 100K, like 75 to 150-ishK is what you said. Most enterprises are used to buying. So instead of starting or even sticking with 10K, 20K for too long, you need to make yourself go towards 75 to 150K.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete pricing/packaging target for enterprise sales that pushes teams to move upmarket faster rather than lingering at low ACVs.
